techniques.name: Assumption Mapping
techniques.summary: Visual tool to surface and prioritize risky or uncertain assumptions.
techniques.description: Assumption Mapping helps teams identify and prioritize assumptions that could affect product success. Teams plot assumptions against uncertainty and risk axes to decide which to test first.
techniques.purpose: To reduce product risk by surfacing and validating critical assumptions.
techniques.seo_description: Use Assumption Mapping to uncover and prioritize the assumptions that could derail your product development efforts.

knowledge_examples.title: SmartCart team prioritizes basket automation assumptions
knowledge_examples.description: SmartCart mapped key assumptions like 'users want auto-filled baskets' and flagged it as high-risk and high-uncertainty. This led them to run fake door tests before building.
knowledge_examples.context: Online grocery platform planning a smart basket feature
knowledge_examples.outcome: They avoided building a costly feature by validating the need first.

techniques.name: Story Mapping
techniques.summary: Visual breakdown of user journeys to prioritize features and slices.
techniques.description: Story Mapping is used to visually organize user activities and break them into smaller tasks or slices that help teams prioritize and release iteratively.
techniques.purpose: To structure product development around user needs and deliver value in slices.
techniques.seo_title: Story Mapping – Organize Work Around User Journeys
techniques.seo_description: Use Story Mapping to visually plan product functionality around end-to-end user activities.

knowledge_examples.title: SmartCart meal planning workflow
knowledge_examples.description: Mapped user goals like selecting meals, reviewing ingredients, and confirming delivery. Used to prioritize MVP features.
knowledge_examples.context: Initial release planning for SmartCart’s meal planner
knowledge_examples.outcome: Improved alignment and enabled early release with core flow complete.

techniques.name: Fake Door Testing
techniques.summary: Test feature demand by simulating it before building.
techniques.description: Fake Door Testing helps assess interest in a proposed feature by simulating its presence (e.g., a button or prompt) before development. It provides behavioral validation of user intent.
techniques.purpose: To validate demand for a new feature before investing in development.
techniques.seo_title: Fake Door Testing – Validate Feature Demand
techniques.seo_description: Use Fake Door Testing to assess interest in features before building. Gauge user demand via simulated UI prompts.

knowledge_examples.title: SmartCart auto-replenish test
knowledge_examples.description: The team added a toggle labeled 'Auto-fill my cart weekly' with a 'Coming soon' message behind it. Clicks were tracked to measure demand.
knowledge_examples.context: Validating automation ideas before full build
knowledge_examples.outcome: High click-through rate led to a limited-feature pilot for auto-fill.

techniques.name: Walking Skeleton
techniques.summary: Thin end-to-end implementation of a system to validate integration and architecture.
techniques.description: A Walking Skeleton delivers a minimal, end-to-end implementation of a system to validate integration points and system architecture before expanding features.
techniques.purpose: To reduce architectural risk and validate integration early.
techniques.seo_description: Build a Walking Skeleton to validate architecture and system integrations early with minimal functionality.

knowledge_examples.title: SmartCart login-to-checkout skeleton
knowledge_examples.description: Created a minimal experience from login to scheduling a delivery with one item. No styling, but tested authentication, item DB, and order queue.
knowledge_examples.outcome: Exposed missing API constraints early and accelerated future delivery.

techniques.name: Sunsetting Framework
techniques.summary: Planned removal of underused or harmful features with minimal disruption.
techniques.description: A Sunsetting Framework defines how to identify, communicate, and remove features that no longer serve users or introduce risk, while supporting smooth transitions.
techniques.purpose: To retire features responsibly and maintain a healthy, focused product.
techniques.seo_description: Learn how to sunset underused or risky features using structured communication and transition plans.

knowledge_examples.title: SmartCart retires SMS ordering
knowledge_examples.description: Discovered only 2% usage and high support cost. Notified users, offered voice assistant as an alternative, and removed SMS feature after 30 days.
knowledge_examples.outcome: Reduced support load and improved system focus.
